user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_irq_register:
```c
int metal_irq_register(int irq,
		       metal_irq_handler irq_handler,
		       void *arg)
{
	struct metal_irq_controller *cntr;
	struct metal_irq *irq_data;

	cntr = metal_irq_get_controller(irq);
	if (cntr == NULL) {
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	if (cntr->irq_register != NULL) {
		return cntr->irq_register(cntr, irq, irq_handler, arg);
	}
	if (cntr->irqs == NULL) {
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	irq_data = &cntr->irqs[irq - cntr->irq_base];
	irq_data->hd = irq_handler;
	irq_data->arg = arg;
	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (cntr->irqs == NULL) {
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 14.3 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated. The controlling expression depends on the runtime value of cntr->irqs (cntr is obtained at run time and checked non-NULL earlier), so it is not an invariant. A specific violation scenario would be if cntr->irqs were provably constant at compile time (e.g. a const/global initialized always to NULL or otherwise proven by the compiler to be always true/false), in which case the controlling expression would be invariant — but that is not the case in the presented code.
